Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Variable Field (X-, Q-band) Pulsed EPR Spectrometer for Research and Training
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program (CRIF), Professors Jonas Peters, Theodor Agapie and colleagues from the California Institute of Technology aquire an X-, Q-band pulsed electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrometer and related accessories including electron nuclear double resonance (ENDOR). This instrument allows research in a variety of fields such as those that provide insight on how biologically relevant species with unpaired electrons behave. In general, an EPR spectrometer yields detailed information on the geometric and electronic structure of molecular and solid state materials. It may also be used to obtain information about the lifetimes of free radicals, short-lived, highly reactive species involved in valuable chemical transformations as well as the initiation of pathological tumor growth. In a standard ENDOR experiment, a sample is placed in a magnetic field and irradiated sequentially with a microwave followed by radio frequency. The changes are then detected by monitoring variations in the polarization of the saturated electron paramagnetic resonance transition. These studies impact a number of areas, from the synthesis of inorganic and organic molecules to the development of new solid state materials to compounds of magnetic and biological interest. Employing examples inspired from ongoing research, this instrument is an integral part of research and teaching at the undergraduate and graduate levels at Caltech. Additionally, the investigators have identified a significant number of interested users from the area outside of this institution and also identified a lot of enthusiasm for a hands-on workshop on EPR/pulsed-EPR that is expected to grow the regional user base.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as: (a) the iron-molybdenum co-factor (FeMoco) and nitrogen fixation; (b) models of iron-mediated nitrogen fixation; (c) oxygen-evolving complex in photosynthesis; (d) nickel-catalyzed cross-coupling; (e)photoredox catalysis; (f) spin-active metal-dihydrogen and metal-hydride species; (g) metallonitrenes in catalysis; (h) using C1 and C2 precursors for carbon-carbon couplings; and (i) site directed spin labeling (SDSL) for the study of biogenesis of membrane and secretory proteins.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has allowed the establishment of a state of the art pulse EPR spectroscopy core user facility at Caltech through the acquisition of a new Bruker E-580 pulse X- and Q-band EPR spectrometer. This instrument provides an entirely new capability for multifrequency pulse EPR characterization of open shell chemical species. Pulse EPR methods, particularly electron nuclear double resonance (ENDOR) and hyperfine sublevel correlation (HYSCORE) spectroscopies allow for a highly detailed characterization of the magnetic interactions between unpaired electrons and magnetic nuclei in the vicinity of the center of unpaired spin density that are too small to be resolved in a continuous wave (CW) EPR spectrum. Interpretation of these parameters can provide detailed information about the identity and electronic structure of paramagnetic species as key reaction intermediates, data that are often intractable using other common spectroscopic methods such as NMR (due to paramagnetic broadening) or X-ray crystallography (due to thermal instability of reactive species). Understanding the electronic structures, physical properties, and reactivity patters of radicals represents a frontier area of chemical research that spans many dimensions.

This new EPR capability was of great need in the Division of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering (CCE) at Caltech, considering its diverse array of faculty with exciting research programs pursuing aspects of fundamental synthetic inorganic chemistry, mechanistic studies of catalysis involving reactive open-shell intermediates, as well as the generation of materials containing paramagnetic site-defects or transition metal dopants. This EPR capability was also of much interest to faculty within the Division of Biology and Biological Engineering (BBE) for characterization of paramagnetic cofactors or reaction intermediates (e.g. transition metal centers/clusters and organic radicals) in biological enzymes, as well as other disciplines around the campus.

This new pulse EPR spectrometer and the facility in which it is housed has greatly impacted research at Caltech by offering with new capabilities for characterization of paramagnetic species via advanced EPR techniques. Of equal importance, it provides training in the use of pulsed EPR techniques, from design of the experiment, to data acquisition, to analysis and interpretation. Nationwide, such capabilities (and hence training) are typically restricted to specialized EPR spectroscopy research groups, rather than departmental user facilities in which any university personnel have access and can become proficient. This is rapidly showing an impact on campus as the number of individuals fluent in pulsed EPR grows.

The new instrument and facility are also rapidly having impact beyond Caltech, as the number of users from outside Caltech continues to grow. Researchers from several external universities (e.g., UC Irvine, Univ Kansas) are routinely performing experiments in the facility. As a direct result of the expansion of the Caltech EPR facility, several studies with key insights from advanced EPR techniques have been published in the last 1.5 years, on topics ranging from synthetic nitrogen fixation catalysts to the mechanism of biological arsenic respiration.
